poem:
"Beavers in the Cairngorms"

Reintroduced, nocturnal guests,
hiding in the weft of dusk.
After 400 years of rest,
Arise, make home amidst the bracken.

Ripples whisper their return, 
Argyll's heart echoes in their gnawing.
A beacon of the past reborn;
the forest whispers in the morning. 

Elusive, yet profound, the presence,
In Cairngorms wild, their essence.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Country diary: A disturbance here, a ripple there, and then we spot one | Merryn Glover We know we won’t see them, but we are here for the beavers. After extinction in the UK 400 years ago, and reintroduction in Argyll and other sites from 2009, they were brought to the Cairngorms national park last December. They are settling well, but nocturnal and elusive. It is after 9pm when we drop down a steep bank". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Country diary: A disturbance here, a ripple there, and then we spot one | Merryn Glover We know we won’t see them, but we are here for the beavers. After extinction in the UK 400 years ago, and reintroduction in Argyll and other sites from 2009, they were brought to the Cairngorms national park last December. They are settling well, but nocturnal and elusive. It is after 9pm when we drop down a steep bank
